Sweet poplar shade, whose trembling leaves emong</br>The cheereful birds delight to chaunt their laies;</br>Where oft the linnet powres the dulcet song,</br>And oft the thrilling thrush descanting plaies;</br>Their tunes attempring to the silver Yare,</br>Which gently murmurs here,</br>A babbling brook; but swelling in his pride</br>Sees two fam'd towns upon his bankes appeare,</br>And the tall ships on his faire bosom ride;</br>Indignant then rolls his prowde waves away,</br>And fomes ore half the sea:</br>Sweet stream, with shade refresht, orehung with bowres</br>Entrailed with the honied woodbine faire;</br>Where breathes the gentlest, softest, simplest aire</br>Stealing fresh odors from the rising Flowres,</br>Joy of my calmer howres,</br>O sooth me with thy murmurs whiles I sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

With pleasance oft two silver swannes I view</br>Pranking their silken plumes with conscious pride,</br>A comely couplement of goodly hew,</br>Come softly swimming down the crystal tide;</br>The crystal tide, resplendent as it may,</br>Looks not so faire as they,</br>Whether their snowie necks they love to lave,</br>Or pluck with jettie bill in wanton play</br>The yellow flowres that fote upon the wave;</br>Or sdeigne to tinge their plumage, lest they might</br>Soyle their pure beauties bright;</br>But with slow pomp on the clear surface move.</br>Sweet cygnets, whiter than the new faln snow</br>That silvers ore Thessalian Pindus brow;</br>Purer than those that draw the queen of love,</br>Fayrer than Laeda's Jove,</br>Tune your melodious voices whiles I sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Oft when the modest morn in purple drest,</br>Wak'd by the lively larke's love-learned laye,</br>Unbars the golden light gate of the east,</br>And as a bridemaid leads the blushing daye;</br>The sunnes bright harbinger before her goes</br>Scattering violet, scattering rose;</br>The jolly sunne, uprist with lusty pride,</br>Shakes his fair amber locks, and round him throws</br>His glitterand beams to wellcome up his bride;</br>Then bids his livery'd clouds before him flie,</br>And daunces up the skie.</br>Sweet is the breath of heaven with day spring born;</br>Sweet are the flowres, that ore the damaskt meads</br>To the new sunne unfold their velvet heads;</br>Sweet is the dewe, the spangled child of morn,</br>That does the leaves adorn;</br>Sweet is the matin hymne the glad birds sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

With early step yon verdant slope I tread</br>Crown'd with the florisht bowre of cremosin health;</br>Whence auntient Norwic rears her towred head,</br>Norwic, fair nurse of industrie and wealth!</br>Down in the dale my lowly hamlet lies,</br>Where truth without disguise,</br>Where dove-like peace, and virgin virtue where.</br>Hence Bacon's villa greets my pleasur'd eyes;</br>Bacon to Phoebus and the Muses deare,</br>Seeking, uncombred with the toyles of state,</br>This grove-embosom'd seate.</br>The tufted hill, the valley flowre-bedight,</br>The silver shinings of my winding Yare,</br>The corn green-springing, and the fallows seare,</br>The lambkins sporting round, rural delight,</br>From hence enchaunt the sight,</br>And wake the rural pipe, and tempt to sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Oft when the eve demure with dewy eye,</br>Clad in a lengthned stole of raven-gray,</br>Assumes the sober empire of the skye,</br>The streakt west glimmering to the parting day;</br>When golden Hesperus, forth-streaming bright,</br>The leader of the night,</br>Marshals his radiant troopes, and gives command</br>In heaven's hie arch their lovely lamps to light;</br>Shouting he walks the Gideon of the band:</br>When first the youthfull moon begins to show</br>New-bent her blessed bow;</br>When, or uprising from her eastern bowre</br>Full-orb'd she strives her glowing face to shroud,</br>Gorgeously mantled in a lucid cloud;</br>Or all her beaming brightness deignes to powre</br>The silver'd landskip o'er;</br>And shepherd swains their evening carrols sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring,

Ore the new shaven level green I rove,</br>Where the fresh haycock breathes along the mead,</br>Or wander thro' th' uncertain shaded grove,</br>Or the trim margent of the river tread;</br>Where the soft murmurs of the poplars tall,</br>To the streames liquid fall</br>Attempred sweet, the museful mind delight;</br>Where the lone partridge to her mate does call,</br>Responsive in his homeward-hasting flight;</br>Where the lowe quail with modulation bland</br>Runnes piping ore the land;</br>Where, as I stray along the upland ground,</br>The farre-off clock just trembles to my ear;</br>Where the mad citties louder mirth I hear,</br>When swinging in full peal, a festive sound,</br>The deep bells roar around:</br>In mute attention hush'd I cease to sing;</br>Nor hills, nor dales, nor woods, nor fountaines ring.

Now night's pale fires a peacefull influence shed,</br>The flockes forget to bleat, the herds to low,</br>Loosely along the grassie green dispred:</br>The slumbring trees seem their tall tops to bow,</br>Rocking the careless birds that on them nest</br>To gentle, gentle rest;</br>Silent each one, save the lone nightingale,</br>Of all the tuneful sisters sweetest, best;</br>She, soft musitian, thro' th' encharmed dale</br>Powres dainty-dittied warbling to delight</br>The stillness of the night.</br>'Tis sacred thus to tread the dewy glade;</br>In the calme solitude of that still howre</br>To nature's God, the gratefull soul to powre</br>Or in the silvery shine, or doubtfull shade</br>By quivering branches made:</br>Rapt with the aweful thought I cease to sing;</br>Nor hills, nor dales, nor woods, nor fountaines ring.

When flaming in the zenith of his powre,</br>Darting directly down his fiery ray,</br>The hotte sunne, leaving his meridian bowre,</br>Enfevers with his beams the cloudlesse day;</br>The gadding herd from such a fervent skie</br>To the cool thicket flie,</br>Tormented with the bryzes teazefull sting;</br>Th' enduring sheep in th' hot sands panting lie;</br>The grashoppers, blithe insects, daunce and sing;</br>The mower swart his sweeping scythe forsakes,</br>The damzels quit their rakes,</br>And seated where the freshing shade is found</br>With joyous jolliment the daye beguile;</br>Sweet is the quaver'd laugh, the simper'd smile,</br>When, as the tale or gamesome song goes round,</br>The vocal vales resound;</br>Nor less to me, whiles I essay to sing,</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Ye lordings great, that in prowde citties wonne,</br>Which gently-cooling breezes never blesse;</br>In gorgeous palaces with heat foredonne,</br>Come here and envy at my littlenesse.</br>All on a hanging hill, a simple home,</br>For its small tenant roome,</br>Safe-nested in the bosom of a grove,</br>Where pride, and strife, and envie never come,</br>Nor any cares, save the sweet cares of love:</br>A little garden gives a cool retreat</br>From the daies powrefull heat;</br>Where flowes my gentle Yare, whose bankes along</br>Th' inwoven branches, like a girlond made,</br>With wanton wreathing decke a daintie shade;</br>While the smooth watry glass, reflecting strong,</br>With bending bankes, and shades respondent vies,</br>Pointing to downward skies:</br>Here in this soft enclosure whiles I sing,</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Here bountious nature, like a virgin faire,</br>Whose ladie fingers deck the velvet green</br>With cunning colourings of broidery rare</br>Sweetly enterchang'd the varied shades atween,</br>The grassie groundsoil, as a lovely bride,</br>Hath richly beautifide,</br>Strowing the primrose pale, the violet blew,</br>The silver'd snow drop, and the daisie pied,</br>The crocus glistering in its golden hew,</br>The cowslip drops of Amber weeping still,</br>The flaunting daffodil,</br>The virgin lillie, and the modest rose,</br>The prettie pink, the red and white yfere;</br>Flowres of all hewes that paint the various yeare;</br>And the mild zephyr, that emong them blows,</br>Around sweet odors throws,</br>Scenting the soft enclosure where I sing,</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

The chemist bee with busy murmurings</br>Extracts the soul of sweetness from each flowre,</br>Such as the Syracosian Thyrsis sings,</br>All in the shadow of the shepherd's bowre;</br>The stock-doves, darlings of the Mantuan swaine,</br>In melting murmurs plaine;</br>Sweet birds of such a swaine to be the care,</br>The sootest he that ever chaunted straine,</br>Or with the gladful pipe enthrald the ear;</br>Him, as he sung, the graces dauncing round,</br>With their own girlonds crown'd;</br>The nymphes that haunt the river and the grove,</br>Whether his skilful reed he sweetly charms,</br>Or strikes the sounding lyre, and sings of arms,</br>Apollo him, and him the Muses love</br>Their own blest quire above:</br>Ah!  would they deigne their visits whiles I sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Here the poetic birds no fear molests:</br>Did I, sweet tenants of my garden, say,</br>With ruthlesse hand ere marre your prettie nests,</br>Or steal th' unfeather'd innocence away?</br>For you my trees the spring's gay livery wear,</br>For you the ripening year</br>Purples the plum, in the deep cherrie glows,</br>And tempers the rich honie of the pear;</br>For you the laughing vine with nectar flows;</br>For you the permain, comely to behold,</br>Glows with irradiate gold,</br>The burnisht bough vermilioning; for you</br>The mellow'd fruit beyond its time has hung;</br>Well have you paid me, for you well have sung.</br>On nature's musick shall we not bestowe</br>Gifts we to nature owe?</br>Fond of our fellow poets while they sing,</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

An academic leisure here I find</br>With learning's lore to discipline my youth;</br>By virtue's wholesome rules to form my mind,</br>To seek and love the wise man's treasure, truth.</br>Oft too thy hallow'd sons enthroned hie,</br>O peerlesse poesie!</br>Sounding great thoughts my raptur'd mind delight;</br>He first, the glorious child of libertie,</br>Maeonian Milton, beaming heavenly bright;</br>He who full fetously the tale ytold,</br>The Kentish Tityrus old;</br>And he above the pride of greatness great,</br>Sweet Cowley, with the gentlest spirit blest</br>That ever breath'd a calme in humane brest;</br>Who the poor muses richest manor seat</br>The garden's mild retreat,</br>Wrapt in the arms of quiet lov'd to sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

And he, forth-beaming thro' the mystic shade</br>In all the might of magic sweetly strong;</br>Who steep'd in teares the pitious lines he made,</br>The tenderest bard that ere empassion'd song:</br>Or when of love's delights he cast to play,</br>Couth deftly dight the lay;</br>And with gay girlonds goodly beautifide,</br>Bound trew-love-wise to grace his bridale day,</br>With dainty carrols hymn'd this happy bride;</br>Lov'd Spenser, of trew verse the well-spring sweet!</br>The footing of whose feet I, painefull follower, assay to trace.</br>Bring fayrest flowres, the purest lillies bring,</br>With all the purple pride of all the spring;</br>And make great store of poses trim, to grace</br>The prince of poets race;</br>And hymen, hymen, io hymen sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Witness ye hills, and dales, and woods, and plains,</br>Th' unmoved quiet of my silver daies,</br>Free here from all the cares, and all the pains</br>Whose storms do threat the citties dangerous waies:</br>There falsing forgery, and foule defame,</br>And lust of sclanderous blame;</br>There cancred tongues, school'd in th' ungracious art</br>To blast the bloosme of a well-deemed name;</br>Their malice wonneth deep in hollow hart;</br>Ambition there and pride, the lies of life,</br>Sleek guile, and carled strife:</br>Away plain honestie of simple eye,</br>And dove-like peace that calms the shepherd's day;</br>Away each science, and each muse away,</br>And single truth, and sunne-bright honour flie:</br>And lovely libertie:</br>Here then, sweet shade, O shield me whiles I sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountaines ring.

Thus on his rustic reed the recklesse swaine,</br>Smit with the peacefull joys of lowly life,</br>The world's gay shews forgiving, charm'd the plaine,</br>Withouten envie, and withouten strife:</br>All on a knot-grass bank, ore arched hie</br>With ivy-canopie,</br>And with wild roses richly well inwove,</br>He lay, and tun'd his rural minstrelsie;</br>When, lo!  the favouring genius of the grove,</br>Fair Physis nam'd, to his entranced sight</br>Appeared heavenly bright:</br>Loose her fine tresses flow'd, like golden wire,</br>With budding flowrets perled all atween,</br>And shaded with a daintie girlond green;</br>And aye in green she did herself attire:</br>Beneath her feet in youthful rich array</br>A voluntary May</br>Threw sweets, threw flowres; the birds more joyous sing;</br>The hills, the dales, the woods, the fountains ring.

Then with a smile that brighten'd all the shade,</br>Mild she bespake, and deign'd to press his hand,</br>Enough, fond youth, to Physis has been paid</br>Break then thy rural pipe at her command:</br>These woodnotes wild, this flowre-perfumed aire,</br>And thy sweet-streaming yare</br>Must charm no more; no more the hallow'd cell,</br>Where white rob'd peace, and free-born fancy faire</br>With sacred solitude delight to dwell.</br>Wake then the spark of glorious great intent</br>In action excellent</br>That fires the noble-passion'd soul to shine:</br>In all the depths of useful lore engage,</br>To grace thy youth, and dignifie thine age:</br>Ne ween that Physis bids those paths decline,</br>For all those paths are mine.</br>Change then the straine; to hill, to valley tell</br>Farewells sweet shade:  sweet poplar shade, farewell.

But, ah!  beware; for in this goodly chace</br>A vile enchauntress spreds her vaine delights;</br>With guilefull semblants charming all that pass,</br>Till she enslaved hath their feeble sprights:</br>And sooth she is to view a lady faire,</br>Of beauty past compare:</br>And aye around her croud a gorgeous throng,</br>Skill'd in the mincing step, the vestment rare,</br>And the fine squeaking of an eunuch's song;</br>But sacred science, tender love, trew fame,</br>And honor's heaven born flame</br>They know not; yet the pompous name vertù</br>To th' idle pageant give:  she cruel prowd</br>Deals magic charms emong the carelesse crowd,</br>And does them all to hideous apes transmew.</br>But fear not thou the minion's magic pride,</br>For Physis is thy guide:</br>Come then:  to hill, to dale this burden tell,</br>Farewell, sweet shade:  sweet poplar shade, farewell.

To Cosme's polish'd court thy steps I'll lead,</br>My sister she, tho' eft we strangers seem;</br>Far otherwise of us the wise aread,</br>But follies feeble eyes of things misdeem.</br>The straw roof'd cott, the pastur'd mead I love,</br>The mavis-haunted grove,</br>The moss-clad mountaine hoar, a rugged scene;</br>Along the streamlet's mazy margent rove,</br>That sweetly steals the broken rocks atween:</br>She thro' the manner'd cittie powres the flame</br>Of high atchieved fame,</br>The star-bright guerdon of the great and good;</br>And breathes her vivid spirit in the mind</br>Whose generous aimes extend to all mankind,</br>And vindicate the worth of noble blood;</br>Such as, in bowre Lycaean holding place,</br>The man of Spargrove grace:</br>Come then; to hill, to dale this burden tell,</br>Farewell, sweet shade:  sweet poplar shade, farewell,

Als like a girlond her enring around</br>The sphere born Muses lyring heavenly strains;</br>The graces eke with bosoms all unzon'd,</br>A trinal band that concord sweet maintains;</br>And who is she that, placed them atween,</br>Seems a fourth grace I ween?</br>So looks the rubie pretious rare, enchaced</br>In the bright crownet of a maiden queen.</br>Each science too with verdant bay leaves graced,</br>With honour brought from Attic land again,</br>Adorns the radiant train.</br>Come then, let nobler aimes thy soul inspire:</br>But bring the cherub Innocence along,</br>And Contemplation sage, on pineon strong</br>High-soaring ore yon lamping orb of fire—</br>Thus pip'd the Doric oate, while echoes shrill,</br>To fountaine, dale, and hill</br>Resyllabling the notes, this burden tell,</br>Farewell, sweet shade:  sweet poplar shades farewell.</br>
